Drink up, Pop. It's closing time.
But it's early, Charlie.
Don't you know what night this is?
I know, Charlie. I know. I work for the outfit. He polishes off his drink, walks out unsteadily. The bartender approaches the dancers.

Hey, knock it off, will you? Go home. Bud and Margie ignore him, continue dancing -- or rather swaying limply cheek-to-cheek. The bartender crosses to t juke box, pulls the plug out. The music stops, but not Bu and Margie -- they continue dancing.
O-U-T -- out! He goes to the front of the bar, starts to extinguish the lights. Margie picks up her handbag from the bar, and Bud downs the remains of his drink.
Where do we go -- my place or yours?
(peering at his watch)
Might as well go to mine -- everybody else does. He leads her through the dark bar toward the entrance. Th bartender holds the door open for them as they go out.
Bud and Margie come walking down the street. As they reac the house, Bud starts up the steps, but Margie continues along the sidewalk.
Poor Mickey -- when I think of him all by himself in that jail in Havana -- (opening her handbag)
-- want to see his picture?
(from steps)
Not particularly. Margie, realizing her mistake, hurries back to join him.
He's so cute -- five-foot-two -- ninety-nine pounds...like a little chihuahua. They pass through the front door into the vestibule.
Bud and Margie are mounting the stairs toward the apartme
Can I ask you a personal question?
No.
You got a girl-friend?
She may be a girl -- but she's no friend of mine.
Still stuck on her, huh.
Stuck on her! Obviously, you don't know me very well.
I don't know you at all.
Permit me -- C.C. Baxter -- junior executive, Arthur Murray graduate, lover.
I'm Mrs. MacDougall -- Margie to you. Bud has taken the key out of his pocket, opened the door his apartment.
This way, Mrs. MacDougall. He ushers her in.
It is exactly the way we left it. There is no sign of Fra except for the gloves she dropped on the coffee table earlier. Bud switches on the light, shuts the door.
(looking around)
Say, this is Snugsville.
(helping her out of her coat)
Mrs. MacDougall, I think it is only fair to warn you that you are now alone with a notorious sexpot.
(a gleam)
No kidding.
Ask anybody around here. As a matter of fact, when it's time for me to go -- and I may go just like that -- (snaps his fingers)
-- I have promised my body to the Columbia Medical Center.
(shuddering deliciously)
Gee. Sort of gives you goose-bumps just to think about it.
Well, they haven't got me yet, baby. Dig up some ice from the kitchen and let's not waste any time -- preliminary-wise.

I'm with you, lover. She takes the bowl of melted ice Bud has handed her, disappears into the kitchen. As Bud starts to remove his coat, he becomes aware of a scratching noise from the phonograph. He crosses to it, sees that the needle is stu in the last groove of a long-playing record. Bud lifts the record off, examines it curiously, then put it aside and substitutes the cha cha record. As the music starts, he dances over to the coat-rack beside the door, hangs up his chesterfield and bowler. He turns back into room, still dancing, suddenly spots Fran's gloves on the coffee table. He picks up the gloves, looks around for so convenient place to get rid of them. Moving over to the bedroom door, he opens it, tosses the gloves toward the b inside. He shuts the door, starts to turn away, freezes i delayed reaction to something he saw inside. He quickly opens the door again, looks. Sprawled across the bed, on top of the bedspread, is Fran The light from the bathroom falls across her. She is full dressed, still in her coat, and apparently asleep. Bud steps into the bedroom, closing the door behind him, walks over to Fran.
All right, Miss Kubelik -- get up. It's past checking-out time, and the hotel management would appreciate it if you would get the hell out of here. (Fran doesn't stir)
Look, Miss Kubelik, I used to like you -- I used to like you a lot -- but it's all over between us -- so beat it -- O-U-T -- out! (no reaction; he puts a hand on her shoulder, shakes her)
Come on -- wake up! She doesn't respond. But something falls out of her hand, rolls across the bed. Bud picks it up, looks at it -- it his sleeping-pill vial, now uncapped and empty.
(a hoarse whisper)
Oh, my God. For a second he is paralyzed. Then he drops the vial, gra Fran, lifts her into a sitting position on the bed, shake her violently.

Miss Kubelik! Miss Kubelik! Fran's head droops to one side, like a rag doll's. Bud le go of her, rushes out. In the living room, the phonograph is still cha cha-ing a Bud dashes to the phone, picks it up. Then it occurs to h that he doesn't know whom to call and he hangs up. Out of the kitchen comes Margie, with a bowlful of ice cubes.
I broke a nail trying to get the ice-tray out. You ought to buy yourself a new refrigerator. Bud, not listening, runs past her to the hall door and ou
(calling after him)
I didn't mean right now.
Bud arrives at the door of the Dreyfuss apartment, starts ringing the doorbell and pounding with his fist.
Dr. Dreyfuss! Hey, Doc! The door opens, and Dr. Dreyfuss stands there sleepily, pulling on his beaten bathrobe.
(words tumbling over each other)
There's a girl in my place -- she took some sleeping pills -- you better come quick -- I can't wake her up.
Let me get my bag. He disappears from the doorway.
Hurry up, Doc. Bud turns and runs back into his apartment.
Margie has settled herself comfortably on the couch, and fixing the drinks. The cha cha music is still going. Bud comes flying in, heads for the bedroom.
Hey -- over here, lover. Bud stops in his tracks, suddenly aware of her.
What's all this running around? You're going to wear yourself out. Bud strides over to her purposefully, yanks her up to her feet.
Not so rough, honey.
(taking the glass out of her hand)
Good night.
Good night?
(thrusting the fur coat at her)
The party's over.
What's the matter? Did I do something wrong?
(easing her toward door)
It's an emergency -- see you some other time. Dr. Dreyfuss comes hurrying in, carrying his medical bag. stops, bewildered by the sound of music and the sight of wide-awake girl in the apartment.
Not this one -- (pointing to the bedroom)
-- in there, Doc. Dr. Dreyfuss proceeds into the bedroom.
Say, what's going on here, anyway?
Nothing. (propelling her toward the door)
Just clear out, will you?
(pointing back)
My shoes. Bud reaches under the coffee table, where she left her shoes, retrieves them.
(bitterly)
Some lover you are. Some sexpot! Bud shoves the shoes at her, takes a bill out of his wall hands it to her.
Here -- find yourself a phone booth and call your husband in Havana.
You bet I will. And when I tell him how you treated me, he'll push your face in. (he shoves her through the open door)

You fink! Bud slams the door shut, starts toward the bedroom. Halfw there, he becomes aware that the cha cha record is still He detours to the phonograph, switches it off, continues into the bedroom. In the bedroom, the overhead light is on, and Dr. Dreyfus is working on the unconscious Fran. He has removed her co and is shining a flashlight into her eyes, examining her pupils. Bud approaches the bed worriedly.
She going to be all right, Doc?
How many pills were in that bottle?

It was half-full -- about a dozen or so. You going to have to take her to the hospital? Dr. Dreyfuss ignores him. Out of his medical bag, he take stomach tube with a rubber funnel at the end. Then he sta to lift Fran off the bed.
Help me, will you? Between them, they get Fran into an upright position.
Into the bathroom. They half-carry, half-drag Fran's limp form toward the bathroom.
What are you going to do, Doc?

Get that stuff out of her stomach -- if it isn't too late. You better put some coffee on -- and pray. Bud starts away as Dr. Dreyfuss takes Fran into the bathr Bud loses no time getting into the kitchen. He fills an aluminum kettle with water, strikes a match, lights the g burner, puts the kettle on. Then he takes a jar of instan coffee and a chipped coffee mug out of the cupboard, shak an excessive portion of coffee into the mug, sticks a spo in it. He watches the kettle for a moment, mops his brow with a handkerchief, then starts back toward the bedroom. Bud crosses the bedroom to the half-open door of the bathroom, looks in anxiously. From inside come the sounds a coughing spasm and running water. Bud turns away, undoe his tie and collar, paces the bedroom floor. Something on the night table attracts his attention -- resting against the base of the lamp is a sealed envelope. Bud picks it up -- on it, in Fran's handwriting, is one word, JEFF. He turns the letter over in his hand, trying to decide what do with it. Dr. Dreyfuss emerges from the bathroom, carrying a pale, still unconscious Fran. Bud quickly conceals the suicide note behind his back.

Bring my bag. He lugs Fran into the living room. Bud stashes the letter his back pocket, picks up the medical bag, follows them. In the living room, Dr. Dreyfuss lowers Fran into a chair Her chin falls to her chest. Dreyfuss takes the bag from Bud, fishes out a hypodermic syringe, draws 2 c.c.'s from bottle of picrotoxin.
Roll up her right sleeve. Bud does so. Dr. Dreyfuss hands the hypodermic to Bud, searches for a spot for the injection.
Nice veins. He swabs the spot with alcohol, takes the hypodermic back from Bud.
Want to tell me what happened?
I don't know -- I mean -- I wasn't here -- you see -- we had some words earlier -- nothing serious, really -- what you might call a lovers' quarrel --
(making off-scene injection)
So you went right out and picked yourself up another dame.
Something like that.

You know, Baxter, you're a real cutie-pie -- yes, you are. Bud just stands there, taking it. Fran stirs slightly, an from her parched lips comes a low moan. Dr. Dreyfuss grab her by the hair, lifts her head up.

If you'd come home half an hour later, you would have had quite a Christmas present. With his free hand, Dr. Dreyfuss slaps Fran viciously acr the face. Bud winces. Dreyfuss, still holding Fran by the hair, takes a box of ammonia ampules out of his bag. He crushes one of the ampules in his hand, passes it under h nose. Fran tries to turn her head away. Dreyfuss slaps he again, hard, crushes another ampule, repeats the process. Bud is watching tensely. From the kitchen comes the whist of the boiling kettle, but Bud pays no attention.

Get the coffee. Bud hurries into the kitchen. He turns off the gas, pours the boiling water into the mug with the instant coffee, stirs it. From off, come the sounds of more slapping and some moaning. Bud carries the coffee out. In the living room, Dr. Dreyfuss is working another ammon ampule under Fran's nose. Her eyes start fluttering. Drey takes the coffee mug from Bud, forces it between Fran's lips, pours coffee into her mouth. Fran resists instinctively, half the coffee dribbling over her chin an dress, but Dr. Dreyfuss keeps at it.
Let's get some air in here. Open the windows. Bud complies promptly -- pulls up the shades, opens the windows wide.
(putting the empty mug down)
What's her name?
Miss Kubelik -- Fran.
(to Fran, slowly)
Fran, I'm a doctor. I'm here because you took too many sleeping pills. Do you understand what I'm saying? (Fran mutters something)
Fran, I'm Dr. Dreyfuss -- I'm here to help you. You took all those sleeping pills -- remember?
(mumbling groggily)
Sleeping pills.
That's right, Fran. And I'm a doctor.
Doctor.
Dr. Dreyfuss.
Dreyfuss.
(to Bud)
Get more coffee. Bud picks up the mug, leaves.
(to Fran)
Tell me again -- what's my name?
Dr. Dreyfuss.
And what happened to you?
I took sleeping pills.
Do you know where you are, Fran?
(looking around blankly)
No.
Yes, you do. Now concentrate.
I don't know. Bud is coming back with the coffee.
(pointing to Bud)
Do you know who this is? (Fran tries to focus)
Look at him.
Mr. Baxter -- nineteenth floor.
Hello, Miss Kubelik.
(to Bud)
Mister -- Miss -- such politeness!
(to Dr. Dreyfuss, discreetly)
Well -- we work in the same building -- and we try to keep it quiet --
(to Bud, puzzled)
What are you doing here? Bud throws Dr. Dreyfuss a look, as if to say that Fran's mind still wasn't functioning properly.
(to Fran)
Don't you remember? We were at the office party together --
Oh, yes -- office party -- Miss Olsen --
That's right. (to Dr. Dreyfuss; improvising rapidly)
I told you we had a fight -- that's what it was about -- Miss Olsen -- you know that other girl you saw --
(still trying to figure out Bud's presence)
I don't understand --
It's not important, Fran -- the main thing is that I got here in time -- and you're going to be all right -- (to Dr. Dreyfuss)
-- isn't she, Doc?
(closing her eyes)
I'm so tired --
Here -- drink this. He forces her to swallow some coffee.
(pushing the mug away)
Please -- just let me sleep.
You can't sleep. (shaking her)
Come on, Fran -- open your eyes. (to Bud)

Let's get her walking. We've got to keep her awake for the next couple of hours. They lift her from the chair, and each draping one of her arms over his shoulder, they start to walk her up and dow the room.
(urging Fran on)

Now walk, Fran. One, two, three, four -- one, two, three, four -- that's the idea -- left, right, left, right -- now we turn -- one, two, three, four -- At first, Fran's feet just drag along the floor between t But gradually, as Dr. Dreyfuss' voice continues droning hypnotically, she falls into the rhythm of it, repeating words after him and putting her weight on her feet.
Left, right, left, right -- walk, walk, walk -- one, two, three, four -- turn -- left, right, left, right -- now you got it --

Through the bedroom window comes the first faint light of dawn. Fran has been put to bed by an exhausted Dr. Dreyfu She is in her slip, and Dreyfuss is just drawing the blan over her. Her eyes are closed, and she is moaning fitfull Watching from the doorway is Bud, in shirtsleeves now, we and disheveled.
She'll sleep on and off for the next twenty-four hours. Of course, she'll have a dandy hangover when she wakes up --
Just as long as she's okay.
(massaging his calves)

These cases are harder on the doctor than on the patient. I ought to charge you by the mile. They have now moved out into the living room, where the overhead light and the Christmas tree bulbs are still on.
Any of that coffee left?
Sure. He goes into the kitchen. Dr. Dreyfuss takes a small note with a fountain pen clipped to it out of his bag, sinks d on the couch.
How do you spell her last name?
(from kitchen)
Kubelik -- with two k's.
What's her address? (no answer from Bud)
Where does she live? Bud appears from the kitchen, stirring the coffee powder a cup of hot water.
(apprehensive)
Why do you want to know, Doc? You don't have to report this, do you?
It's regulations.
(setting the coffee down)

She didn't mean it, Doc -- it was an accident -- she had a little too much to drink and -- she didn't know what she was doing -- there was no suicide note or anything -- believe me, Doc, I'm not thinking about myself --
(sipping the hot coffee)
Aren't you?
It's just that she's got a family -- and there's the people in the office -- look, Doc, can't you forget you're a doctor -- let's just say you're here as a neighbor --
(a long look at Bud)
Well, as a doctor, I guess I can't prove it wasn't an accident. (closes notebook)
But as your neighbor, I'd like to kick your keester clear around the block. (indicating coffee)
Mind if I cool this off? He uncaps the bottle of Scotch, pours a large slug into h coffee.
Help yourself.
(taking a big gulp of the spiked coffee)
I don't know what you did to that girl in there -- and don't tell me -- but it was bound to happen, the way you carry on. Live now, pay later. Diner's Club! (another swig)
Why don't you grow up, Baxter? Be a mensch! You know what that means?
I'm not sure.
A mansch -- a human being! So you got off easy this time -- so you were lucky --
Yeah, wasn't I?
(finishing coffee)
But you're not out of the woods yet, Baxter -- because most of them try it again! (picks up bag, starts toward door)

You know where I am if you need me. He walks out, closing the door after him. Bud dejectedly turns off the overhead light, kicks out the plug of the Christmas tree lights, trudges into the bedroom. Fran is fast asleep. Bud picks up her dress, gets a hange drapes the dress over it, hangs it from the door. An earl morning chill has invaded the room, and Bud switches an t electric blanket to keep Fran warm. Then he slumps into a chair beside the bed, looks at Fran compassionately. The light on the dial of the electric blanket glows in the grayish room. Bud just sits there, watching Fran.

Mrs. Lieberman, followed by her dog, is climbing the stai to Bud's apartment, puffing asthmatically. She seems quit angry as she arrives at the door and rings the bell. Ther is no answer. She starts knocking impatiently.
Mr. Baxter. Open up already! Finally the door opens a crack, and Bud peers out. He loo like a man who has slept in his clothes -- rumpled, blear eyed, unshaven.
Oh -- Mrs. Lieberman.
So who did you think it was -- Kris Kringle? What was going on here last night?
Last night?
All that marching -- tramp, tramp, tramp -- you were having army maneuvers maybe?
I'm sorry, Mrs. Lieberman -- and I'll never invite those people again.
What you get from renting to bachelors. All night I didn't sleep ten minutes -- and I'm sure you woke up Dr. Dreyfuss.
Don't worry about Dr. Dreyfuss -- I happen to know he was out on a case.
I'm warning you, Mr. Baxter -- this is a respectable house, not a honky-tonky. (to the dog)
Come on, Oscar. Bud watches her start down the stairs with the dog, withd into the apartment.

Bud closes the door, crosses toward the bedroom, looks inside. Fran is asleep under the electric blanket, breath evenly. He tries to shut the bedroom door, but it won't close completely because Fran's dress, on a hanger. is hooked over the top. He goes to the phone, picks it up, dials the operator.
(his voice low)
Operator, I want White Plains, New York -- Mr. J. D. Sheldrake -- (an added thought)
-- make it person to person.

The decor is split-level Early American. There is a huge Christmas tree and a jumble of presents, open gift boxes, and discarded wrappings. Sheldrake and his two sons, TOMMY and JEFF JR., are squat on the floor, testing a Cape Canaveral set the kids got f Christmas. Sheldrake is in a brand new dressing gown, wit manufacturer's tag still dangling from it, and the boys a in pajamas and astronaut's helmets. As for the Cape Canav set, it is a miniature layout of block-houses, launching pads, and assorted space-missiles. Tommy has his finger o the button controlling one of the rockets.
(counting down)
7-6-5-4-3-2-1 -- let her rip! Tommy presses the button, and a spring sends the rocket toward the ceiling. Just then, the phone in the entrance hall starts ringing.
I'll get it. He hurries to the phone.
Hey, Dad -- why don't we put a fly in the nose cone and see if we can bring it back alive?
It's a thought.
Maybe we should send up two flies -- and see if they'll propagate in orbit.
See if they'll what?
Propagate -- you know, multiply -- baby flies?
Oh -- oh!
(coming back from the phone)
It's for you, Dad. A Mr. Baxter.
(getting up)
Baxter?
Person to person. Sheldrake heads quickly for the phone.
(to Jeff Jr.)
Come on -- help me round up some flies. In the entrance hall, Sheldrake picks up the phone, turns his back toward the living room, speaks in a low voice.
Hello? -- yes -- what's on your mind, Baxter?
I hate to disturb you, but something came up -- it's rather important -- and I think it would be a good idea if you could see me -- at the apartment -- as soon as possible.
You're not making sense, Baxter. What's this all about?
I didn't want to tell you over the phone but that certain party -- you know who I mean -- I found her here last night -- she had taken an overdose of sleeping pills.
What? From the stairway beyond him comes:
What is it, Jeff? Who's on the phone? Sheldrake turns from the phone. Halfway down the stairs i Mrs. Sheldrake, in a quilted house-robe.
(a nice recovery)
One of our employees had an accident -- I don't know why they bother me with these things on Christmas Day. (into phone)
Yes, Baxter -- just how serious is it? Out of the corner of his eye, he watches Mrs. Sheldrake c down the stairs, pass behind him on the way to the living room.
Well, it was touch and go there for a while -- but she's sleeping it off now. He glances through the half-open door toward the sleeping Fran.
I thought maybe you'd like to be here when she wakes up.
That's impossible. (an apprehensive look toward the living room)
You'll have to handle this situation yourself -- as a matter of fact, I'm counting on you --
(into phone)
Yes, sir -- I understand. (taking Fran's letter out of his pocket)
She left a note -- you want me to open it and read it to you? (a beat)

Well, it was just a suggestion -- no, you don't have to worry about that, Mr. Sheldrake -- I kept your name out of it so there'll be no trouble, police-wise or newspaper- wise -- As Bud continues talking on the phone, Fran, in the bedro opens her eyes, looks around vaguely, trying to figure ou where she is. She sits up in bed, winces, holds her head her hands -- she has a fierce hangover.
(into phone)

-- you see, the doctor, he's a friend of mine -- we were very lucky in that respect -- actually, he thinks she's my girl -- no, he just jumped to the conclusion -- around here, I'm known as quite a ladies' man -- In the bedroom Fran, becoming aware of Bud's voice, crawl out of bed and holding on to the furniture, moves unstead toward the living room door.
(into phone)

-- of course, we're not out of the woods yet -- sometimes they try it again -- yes sir, I'll do my best -- it looks like it'll be a couple of days before she's fully recovered, and I may have a little problem with the landlady -- Behind him, Fran appears in the bedroom doorway, barefoot and in her slip. She leans groggily against the door post trying to focus on Bud and to concentrate on what he's sa
(into phone)

-- all right, Mr. Sheldrake, I'll keep her in my apartment as long as I can -- any sort of message you want me to give her? -- well, I'll think of something -- goodbye, Mr. Sheldrake. He hangs up the phone slowly.
(weakly)
I'm sorry. Bud turns around, sees her standing there on rubbery legs
I'm sorry, Mr. Baxter.
Miss Kubelik -- (hurries toward her)
-- you shouldn't be out of bed.
I didn't know -- I had no idea this was your apartment --
(putting his arm around her)
Let me help you. He leads her back into the bedroom.
I'm so ashamed. Why didn't you just let me die?
What kind of talk is that? (he lowers her onto the bed)
So you got a little over- emotional -- but you're fine now.
(a groan)
My head -- it feels like a big wad of chewing gum. What time is it?
Two o'clock.
(struggling to her feet)
Where's my dress? I have to go home. Her knees buckle. Bud catches her.
You're in no condition to go anywhere -- except back to bed.
You don't want me here --
Sure I do. It's always nice to have company for Christmas. He tries to put her back to bed. Fran resists.
Miss Kubelik, I'm stronger than you are --
I just want to go brush my teeth --
Oh -- of course. I think there's a new toothbrush somewhere. He crosses to the bathroom, takes a plaid robe off the ho on the back of the door, hands it to Fran.

Here -- put this on. In the bathroom, he finds an unused toothbrush in a plast container. His eyes fall on his safety razor. With a glan toward the bedroom, he unscrews the razor, removes the blade, drops it in his shirt pocket. Then he empties the blades from the dispenser, puts those in his pocket. Now notices a bottle of iodine on the medicine shelf, stashes that in another pocket, just as Fran appears in the doorw wearing the robe.
(handing her the toothbrush)
Here. How about some breakfast?
No -- I don't want anything.
I'll fix you some coffee. He crosses the bedroom, heading for the kitchen, stops.
Oh -- we're all out of coffee -- you had quite a lot of it last night -- He thinks for a moment, hurries toward the hall door.

Bud comes out of his apartment, leaving the door half ope heads for the Dreyfuss apartment. He rings the bell, peer down over the banister to make sure Mrs. Lieberman isn't snooping around. Mrs. Dreyfuss opens the door.
Mrs. Dreyfuss, can I borrow some coffee -- and maybe an orange and a couple of eggs?
(contemptuously)
Eggs he asks me for. Oranges. What you need is a good horse-whipping.
Ma'am?
From me the doctor has no secrets. Poor girl -- how could you do a thing like that?
I didn't really do anything -- honest -- I mean, you take a girl out a couple of times a week -- just for laughs -- and right away she thinks you're serious -- marriage-wise.
Big shot! For you, I wouldn't lift a finger -- but for her, I'll fix a little something to eat. She slams the door in his face, Bud starts back to his apartment.
Fran enters shakily from the bedroom, looks around for th phone, locates it, picks it up. As she starts dialing, Bu comes in from the hall.
Who are you calling, Miss Kubelik?
My sister -- she'll want to know what happened to me.
(alarmed)
Wait a minute -- let's talk this over first. (hurries up to her, takes the receiver away)
Just what are you going to tell her?
Well, I haven't figured it out, exactly.
You better figure it out -- exactly. Suppose she asks you why you didn't come home last night?
I'll tell her I spent the night with a friend.
Who?
Someone from the office.
And where are you now?
In his apartment.
His apartment?
I mean -- her apartment.
What's your friend's name?
Baxter.
What's her first name?
Miss. (she is impressed with her own cleverness)
When are you coming home?
As soon as I can walk.
Something wrong with your legs?
No -- it's my stomach.
Your stomach?
They had to pump it out.
(hanging up the phone)
Miss Kubelik, I don't think you ought to call anybody -- not till that chewing gum is out of your head. (leads her into bedroom)
But they'll be worried about me -- my brother-in-law may be calling the police --
That's why we have to be careful -- we don't want to involve anybody -- after all, Mr. Sheldrake is a married man --
Thanks for reminding me. She pulls away from him, starts to get into bed.
(contritely)
I didn't mean it that way -- I was just talking to him on the phone -- he's very concerned about you.
He doesn't give a damn about me.
Oh, you're wrong. He told me --
He's a liar. But that's not the worst part of it -- the worst part is -- I still love him. The doorbell rings.
Must be Mrs. Dreyfuss -- (starts into living room)
-- remember the doctor -- from last night -- that's his wife. He opens the hall door. Mrs. Dreyfuss brushes past him wi a tray full of food.
So where is the victim? (Bud indicates the bedroom)
Max the Knife! She sweeps into the bedroom, Bud tagging along.
(to Fran)
Nu, little lady, how are we feeling today?
I don't know -- kind of dizzy.
Here. The best thing for dizzy is a little noodle soup with chicken -- white meat -- and a glass tea. She sets the tray down on Fran's lap.
Thank you. I'm really not hungry.
Go ahead! Eat! Enjoy! She hands her the soup spoon, turns to Bud.
You wouldn't have such a thing as a napkin, would you?
Well, I have some paper towels --
Beatnik! Go to my kitchen -- third drawer, under the good silver, there is napkins.
Yes, Mrs. Dreyfuss. He starts out with a worried backward glance toward the t Fran is just sitting there, the spoon in her hand, not touching the soup.
So what are you waiting for -- a singing commercial?
I can't eat. Mrs. Dreyfuss takes the spoon from her, starts to feed he

You must eat -- and you must get healthy -- and you must forget him. Such a fine boy he seemed when he first moved in here -- clean and cut -- a regular Ivy Leaguer. Turns out he is King Farouk. Mit the drinking -- mit the cha cha -- mit the no napkins. A girl like you, for the rest of your life you want to cry in your noodle soup? Who needs it! You listen to me, you find yourself a nice, substantial man -- a widower maybe -- and settle down -- instead of nashing all those sleeping pills -- for what, for whom? -- for some Good Time Charlie? (sees Bud approaching with napkin)
Sssh!
(gaily)
One napkin, coming up. (hands it to Fran)
I wish we had some champagne to wrap it around.
(to Fran)
What did I tell you?
(uncomfortable)
Look, Mrs. Dreyfuss, you don't have to wait around. I'll wash the dishes and --
You wash 'em, you break 'em. I'll come back for them later. (to Fran)
If he makes trouble, give me a yell. She exits.
She doesn't seem to like you very much.
Oh, I don't mind. As a matter of fact, I'm sort of flattered -- that anybody should think a girl like you -- would do a thing like this -- over a guy like me.
(glancing at night table)
Oh. Did you find something here -- an envelope -- ?
Yes, I've got it. (takes envelope out of back pocket)
Don't you think we'd better destroy it? So it won't fall into the wrong hands -- ?
Open it. Bud tears open the envelope, takes out Sheldrake's hundre dollars.
There's nothing here but a hundred dollar bill.
That's right. Will you see that Mr. Sheldrake gets it?
(shrugging)
Sure. He puts the money in his pocket.
(holding out tray)
Here -- take this, will you? Bud relieves her of the tray, sets it down.
You want me to move the television set in here? (Fran shakes her head)
You play gin rummy?
I'm not very good at it.
I am. Let me get the cards.
You don't have to entertain me. Bud opens the bureau drawer, takes out a deck of cards, a score pad, and a pencil.

Nothing I'd like better -- you know togetherness. Guess what I did last Christmas. Had an early dinner at the automat, then went to the zoo, then I came home and cleaned up after Mr. Eichelberger -- he had a little eggnog party here. I'm way ahead this year. He pulls a chair up to the bed, starts to shuffle the car
Three across, spades double, high deals. (they cut)
Eight -- ten. (he starts to deal)
(pensively)
I think I'm going to give it all up.
Give what up?
Why do people have to love people, anyway?
Yeah -- I know what you mean. (flips over down card)
Queen.
I don't want it.
Pick a card. She does, and they start playing.
What do you call it when somebody keeps getting smashed up in automobile accidents?
A bad insurance risk?
(nodding)
That's me with men. I've been jinxed from the word go -- first time I was ever kissed was in a cemetery.
A cemetery?
I was fifteen -- we used to go there to smoke. His name was George -- he threw me over for a drum majorette.
Gin. He spreads his hand. Fran lays her cards down, and Bud ad them up.
Thirty-six and twenty-five -- that's sixty-one and two boxes. (enters score on pad)
I just have this talent for falling in love with the wrong guy in the wrong place at the wrong time.
(shuffling)
How many guys were there?
(holding up four fingers)
Three. The last one was manager of a finance company, back home in Pittsburgh -- they found a little shortage in his accounts, but he asked me to wait for him -- he'll be out in 1965.
(pushing the deck toward her)
Cut.
(she does, and he starts dealing)
So I came to New York and moved in with my sister and her husband -- he drives a cab. They sent me to secretarial school, and I applied for a job with Consolidated - but I flunked the typing test --
Too slow?
Oh. I can type up a storm, but I can't spell. So they gave me a pair of white gloves and stuck me in an elevator -- that's how I met Jeff -- (her eyes mist up, and she puts her cards down)
Oh, God, I'm so fouled up. What am I going to do now?
You better win a hand -- you're on a blitz.
Was he really upset when you told him?
Mr. Sheldrake? Oh, yes. Very.
Maybe he does love me -- only he doesn't have the nerve to tell his wife.
I'm sure that's the explanation.
You really think so?
No doubt about it.
(a thoughtful beat, then)
Can I have that pad and the pencil?
(handing her score pad and pencil)
What for?
I'm going to write a letter to Mrs. Sheldrake.
You are?
As one woman to another -- I'm sure she'll understand --
Miss Kubelik, I don't think that's such a good idea. He gently takes the pad and pencil away from her.
Why not?
Well, for one thing, you can't spell. And secondly -- if you did something like that -- you'd hate yourself.
(fighting back tears)
I don't like myself very much anyway.
Pick up your cards and let's go.
Do I have to?
You bet. I got a terrific hand. Fran, her eyes drooping sleepily, picks up her cards, mak a discard.
You sure you want to throw that card?
Sure.
Gin. He removes the cards from her hand, starts to add them up

Fifty-two and twenty-five -- that's seventy-seven -- spades is double -- a hundred and fifty-four -- and four boxes -- you're blitzed in two games. He enters the score on the pad. As he starts to shuffle again, he notices that Fran has slid down on the pillow, that her eyes are closed -- she is asleep. Bud rises, adjusts the blanket over her. He stands there looking at her for a moment, runs his hand over his chin. Realizing he needs a shave, he crosses to the bathroom. In the bathroom, Bud washes his face, squirts some shavin cream into his hand, starts to apply it.

A Volkswagen draws up to the curb in front of the house. Kirkeby gets out on the street side, Sylvia squeezes hers out through the other door. Kirkeby raises the front hood the Volkswagen, reaches into the luggage compartment, tak out a cardboard bucket with a bottle of champagne on ice. Together, he and Sylvia start up the steps of the house, Sylvia already cha cha-ing in anticipation.
In the bathroom, Bud has just finished lathering his face when the doorbell rings. He starts into the bedroom.
(muttering to himself)

All right -- all right, Mrs. Dreyfuss. He glances at the sleeping Fran, picks up the tray, carri it into the living room, pulling the bedroom door closed behind him. But it doesn't shut completely, because of Fran's dress hooked over the top. Bud crosses to the hall door, opens it. Outside are Kirke with the champagne bucket, and Sylvia.
Hi, Baxter.
(blocking the door)
What do you want?
What do I -- ? (to Sylvia)
Just a minute. He pushes his way into the apartment past Bud.
You can't come in.
(closing the door behind him)

What's the matter with you, Buddy- boy? I made a reservation for four o'clock, remember? He heads for the coffee table, sets the champagne down. B shoots a quick glance toward the bedroom door, gets rid o the tray.
Look, you can't stay here. Just take your champagne and go.
Baxter, I don't want to pull rank on you -- but I told the lady it was all set -- you want to make a liar out of me?
Are you going to leave, Mr. Kirkeby, or do I have to throw you out? As Bud spins him around, Kirkeby notices the dress on the bedroom door.
Buddy-boy, why didn't you say so? (indicating dress)
You got yourself a little playmate, huh?
Now will you get out?
Outside the door of Bud's apartment, Sylvia is cha cha-in impatiently. Up the stairs comes Dr. Dreyfuss, in his overcoat and carrying his medical bag.
(knocking on the door)

Hey, come on, what are we waiting for? Open up, will you? She continues cha-cha-ing. Dr. Dreyfuss has unlocked the door to his apartment, and is watching Sylvia, appalled b the fact that Baxter seems to be at it again. He starts inside.
(calling)
Mildred --  ! He shuts the door behind him.
(knocking on Baxter's door)
What's holding things up?
Kirkeby looks toward the door in response to Sylvia's knocking.
Say, why don't we have ourselves a party -- the four of us?
No! He forces Kirkeby toward the hall door. Kirkeby, glancing past him through the partly-open door of the bedroom, catches sight of Fran asleep in bed.
(grinning smugly)
Well, I don't blame you. So you hit the jackpot, eh kid -- I mean, Kubelik-wise? (Bud opens the door, gestures him out)
Don't worry. I won't say a word to anybody.
Kirkeby comes backing out the door of Bud's apartment, mi the champagne bucket.
Stay with it, Buddy-boy! (Bud shuts the door on him)
Come on, Sylvia.
What gives?
A little mixup in signals. Let's go.
Go where?
(leading her toward stairs)
What's your mother doing this afternoon?
She's home -- stuffing a turkey.
Why don't we send her to a movie -- like Ben-Hur?
That's fine. But what are we going to do about grandma and Uncle Herman and Aunt Sophie and my two nieces --
Bud comes into the bedroom. As he heads for the bathroom, Fran stirs slightly, opens her eyes.
Who was that?
Just somebody delivering a bottle of champagne. Like some?
(shaking her head)
Would you mind opening the window? She turns off the electric blanket as Bud crosses to the window, pushes it up. Then a thought strikes him, and he looks at Fran suspiciously.
Now don't go getting any ideas, Miss Kubelik.
I just want some fresh air.
It's only one story down -- the best you can do is break a leg.
So they'll shoot me -- like a horse.
(approaching the bed)
Please, Miss Kubelik, you got to promise me you won't do anything foolish.
Who'd care?
I would.
(sleepily)
Why can't I ever fall in love with somebody nice like you?
(ruefully)

Yeah. Well -- that's the way it crumbles, cookie-wise. Go to sleep. Fran closes her eyes. Bud returns to the bathroom, picks his razor, starts to shave. But something seems to be wro with the razor -- and unscrewing it, he realizes that the is no blade. Sheepishly, he takes out the blade he hid in his shirt pocket, inserts it in his razor, screws it shut Then he resumes shaving.
It is the morning after Christmas, and Miss Olsen and the other girls are just settling down to work. Sheldrake, in hat and coat, approaches from the elevators, comes throug the glass doors.
(ad lib)
Good morning, Mr. Sheldrake.
(ignoring them)
Miss Olsen, will you come into my office, please? He strides into the inner office. Miss Olsen picks up her stenographic pad, follows him in.
Sheldrake is removing his hat and coat as Miss Olsen come in, shuts the door behind her.
Did you have a nice Christmas?
Lovely. You were a big help.
Me?
Thank you for giving that little pep talk to Miss Kubelik at the office party.
(dropping her business-like mask)
I'm sorry, Jeff. You know I could never hold my liquor --
But I thought you could hold your tongue.
It won't happen again.
You bet it won't. I'll arrange for you to get a month's severance pay -- (she looks at him, uncomprehending)
That's right, Miss Olsen. I'm letting you go.
(quietly)
You let me go four years ago, Jeff. Only you were cruel enough to make me sit out there and watch the new models pass by.
I'd appreciate it if you'd be out of here as soon as you can.
(formal again)
Yes, Mr. Sheldrake. She turns and walks out of the office, shutting the door. Sheldrake looks after her for a moment, then goes to his desk, picks up the phone, dials the operator.
(into phone)
This is Mr. Sheldrake. I'd like Mr. Baxter's home telephone number -- that's C.C. Baxter, in Ordinary Premium Accounting --

Miss Olsen has put on her coat, and is going through her desk drawers, cleaning out her personal belongings -- nai polish, emery boards, an extra pair of glasses, etc. As s stows them away in her handbag, one of the buttons on the telephone lights up. Miss Olsen hesitates for a second, t with a quick look around, she pushes the button down, carefully picks up the receiver, listens in.
Sheldrake is dialing the last two digits of a telephone number. After a moment, someone answers.
Hello, Baxter? Jeff Sheldrake. Can you talk?
Bud, wearing slacks, a shirt open at the neck, and a card sweater, is at the phone. A pillow and a blanket on the living room couch indicate where he spent the night.
(looking off)
Yes, she's in the shower -- she's coming along fine, considering.
Good. Is there anything you need -- money -- ?
No, thank you, Mr. Sheldrake. As a matter of fact, I've got some money for you -- a hundred dollars --
Oh. (a beat)
Well, if there's anything I can do for you --
For me? I don't think so. But I was hoping maybe you could do something for her --
Like what? Put yourself in my place, Baxter -- how can I help her -- my hands are tied --
Fran now appears in the bedroom, wearing the plaid robe, toweling her damp hair.
(into phone)
Well, at least you can talk to her -- let me put her on -- and please be gentle -- He puts the receiver down, crosses toward the bedroom doo
There's a call for you --
(approaching)
For me?
-- Mr. Sheldrake.
I don't want to talk to him.
I think you should. I have to run down to the grocery anyway -- all that's left around here is one frozen pizza -- (takes raincoat and old hat from hanger)
I'll be right back -- okay? Fran nods, watches him go out. Then she glances toward th phone, which is off the hook. Reluctantly she advances toward it, picks it up.
(into phone)
Hello, Jeff. (a long beat)
Yes, I'm all right.

Fran, why did you do it? It's so childish -- and it never solves anything -- I ought to be very angry with you, scaring me like that -- but let's forget the whole thing -- pretend it never happened -- what do you say, Fran? (no answer)
Fran --
Miss Olsen, glued to the phone, is listening intently.
Are you there, Fran?
Of course I'm not here -- because the whole thing never happened -- I never took those pills -- I never loved you -- we never even met -- isn't that the way you want it?
There you go again -- you know I didn't mean it that way, Fran. Just get well -- do what the nurse tells you -- I mean Baxter -- and I'll see you as soon as I can. Bye, Fran. (he hangs up)

Miss Olsen hangs up the phone, sits there for a moment, weighing what she has overheard. Then she makes a decisio picks up the phone again, dials a number. As she waits fo an answer, she glances toward Sheldrake's office.
(into phone)

Hello, Mrs. Sheldrake? This is Miss Olsen -- fine, thank you -- Mrs. Sheldrake, I was wondering if we could have lunch together? -- well, I don't know how important it is, but I think you might find it educational -- it concerns your husband -- all right, one o'clock, at Longchamp's, Madison and 59th. She looks up as the door to the inner office opens and Sheldrake comes out. He stops when he sees that Miss Olse is still there.
(hanging up phone)
Don't worry, I'm on my way. (she rises)
I was just making a personal call. She opens her handbag, takes out a coin, puts it down on desk.
Here's a dime. She marches out through the glass doors toward the elevat as Sheldrake stands there, watching her.
Bud comes down the street, carrying a large brown paper b overflowing with groceries. He goes up the steps of the house and through the front door.
As Bud starts up the stairs, with the groceries, Mrs. Lieberman comes hurrying down toward him.
(breathlessly)
Oh, Mr. Baxter -- I'm glad you're here -- I was just going to get the passkey.
What for?
I thought I smelled gas coming from your apartment.
Gas? He races up the stairs two at a time, fumbling franticall for his key. Reaching the door of his apartment, he unloc it, dashes in.
Bud comes bursting through the door. The living room is empty, and the bedclothes have been removed from the couc
(calling)

Miss Kubelik! He dumps the bag of groceries on a table, rushes into the kitchen. The burner has been turned on under the kettle, there is no flame, and gas is hissing from the vents. Bud snaps it off, starts out again.

Miss Kubelik! Meanwhile Fran has appeared from the bathroom, and is approaching the bedroom door. She is still in her robe, a is holding a double sock-stretcher with one of Bud's sock on it. Bud, rounding the corner from the kitchen at full speed, collides with Fran in the bedroom doorway. He grab her arms with obvious relief.
Are you all right?
Sure. (sniffs)
What's that funny smell?
Gas. (indicating kitchen)
Didn't you turn it on?
Yes. I was boiling some water to get the coffee stains out of my dress.
(accusingly)
You turned it on -- but you didn't light it.
Are you supposed to?
In this house, you're supposed to.
Oh. Bud starts to take off his hat and coat, notices the sock stretcher in her hand.
What are you doing with that?
I was washing my stockings, so I decided I might as well do your socks.
Thank you.
It's very curious -- I could only find three and a half pair.

Well, things are a little disorganized around here. He carries the bag of groceries into the kitchen, Fran trailing after him. During the following, he removes the contents of the bag -- bread, eggs, bacon, spaghetti, gro round, frankfurters, and assorted canned goods -- sets th out on the drainboard.
I'd say. What's a tennis racquet doing in the kitchen? She produces the racquet from behind the stove.
Tennis racquet? Oh, I remember -- I was cooking myself an Italian dinner. (Fran looks at him oddly)
I used it to strain the spaghetti.
(thinking it over)
Why not?
As a matter of fact, I'm a pretty good cook -- but I'm a lousy housekeeper.
Yes, you are, (indicating the living room)
When I was straightening up the couch, you know what I found? Six hairpins, a lipstick, a pair of false eyelashes, and a swizzle stick from the Stork Club.
(shrugging)
It's just that I'm the kind of guy who can't say no -- I don't mean to girls -- I mean --
You mean to someone like Mr. Sheldrake.
I guess so.
I know so. He's a taker.
A what?
Some people take, some people get took -- and they know they're getting took -- and there's nothing they can do about it.
I wouldn't say that -- (trying to change the subject)
What would you like to have for diner? There's onion soup and canned asparagus --
I really ought to be getting home. My family will be flipping by now. She starts into the living room. Bud follows her.
You can't leave yet. The doctor says it takes forty-eight hours to get the stuff out of your system.
(wistfully)
I wonder how long it takes to get someone you're stuck on out of your system? If they'd only invent some kind of a pump for that -- She sits on the arm of a chair.
I know how you feel, Miss Kubelik. You think it's the end of the world -- but it's not, really. I went through exactly the same thing myself.
You did?
Well, maybe not exactly -- I tried to do it with a gun.
Over a girl?

Worse than that -- she was the wife of my best friend -- and I was mad for her. But I knew it was hopeless -- so I decided to end it all. I went to a pawnshop and bought a forty-five automatic and drove up to Eden Park -- do you know Cincinnati?
No, I don't.

Anyway, I parked the car and loaded the gun -- well, you read in the papers all the time that people shoot themselves, but believe me, it's not that easy -- I mean, how do you do it? -- here, or here, or here -- (with cocked finger, he points to his temple, mouth and chest)
-- you know where I finally shot myself?
Where?
(indicating kneecap)
Here.
In the knee?
Uh-huh. While I was sitting there, trying to make my mind up, a cop stuck his head in the car, because I was illegally parked -- so I started to hide the gun under the seat and it went off -- pow!
(laughing)
That's terrible.

Yeah. Took me a year before I could bend my knee -- but I got over the girl in three weeks. She still lives in Cincinnati, has four kids, gained twenty pounds -- she sends me a fruit cake every Christmas.
(suddenly suspicious)
Are you just making that up to make me feel better?
Of course not. Here's the fruit cake. (shows it to her under Christmas tree)
And you want to see my knee? (starts to raise pant-leg)
No, thanks. The fellows in the office may get the wrong idea how I found out.
So let 'em. Look, I'm going to cook dinner for us. We'll have the fruit cake for dessert. You just sit there and rest. You've done enough for one day.
(smiling)
Yes, nurse. Bud starts happily into the kitchen.

It is mid-afternoon, and traffic is light. A Yellow Cab h pulled up in front of the entrance, and the driver, a stockily-built young man in a leather jacket and cap, get out and comes through the revolving doors into the lobby. His name is KARL MATUSCHKA, and he is Fran's brother-in-l As he cases the elevators, the starter comes up to him.
Can I help you?
I'm looking for one of the elevator girls -- Miss Kubelik.
So am I. She didn't report this morning.
She didn't. Where can I get some information -- who's in charge here?
That comes under General Office Administration. See Mr. Dobisch, twenty-first floor.
Thanks. He steps into an elevator, the doors of which are just closing.
Dobisch is sitting behind his desk, lighting a cigar. Kirkeby, who has dropped in for a little visit, is perche on the edge of the desk.
-- so yesterday afternoon I take Sylvia up to the apartment, and guess who he's got stashed away in the bedroom?
Who?
Kubelik.
No kidding. Buddy-boy and Kubelik having themselves a little toot!
Toot? It's more like a lost weekend. Neither of them showed up for work today.
What gripes me is the two of them were guzzling my champagne while Sylvia and I wound up at the Guggenheim Museum. The glass door opens and Matuschka comes in.
Mr. Dobisch?
Yeah.
My name is Karl Matuschka -- my sister-in-law, she runs one of the elevators here -- Fran Kubelik.
(exchanging a glance with Dobisch)
Miss Kubelik?
You know her?
Of course. There may be a lot of employees here -- but we're one big happy family.
Well, she lives with us -- and my wife, she's getting a little nervous -- on account of Fran hasn't been home for two days.
(another look at Dobisch)
That so.
Anyway, we was wondering if somebody in the office would know what happened to her.
I see. (to Kirkeby)
What do you think, Al? Can we help the man?
(after a pregnant pause)
Why not? We don't owe Buddy-boy anything.
Yeah. What's Buddy-boy done for us lately?
(scowling)
Who is Buddy-boy?

Buddy-boy is bending over a hot stove, preparing an Itali dinner. He takes a saucepan of spaghetti off the fire, an picking up the tennis racquet with the other hand, pours spaghetti on top of the racquet strings. Then he turns on the faucet, runs water over the spaghetti. With the combi technique of Brillat-Savarin and Pancho Gonzales, he gent agitates the racquet, letting the water drain off the spaghetti. As he works, he hums a theme from Tschaikowsky Capriccio Italien. Fran walks in, still in her robe.
Are we dressing for dinner?
No -- just come as you are.
(watching him)
Say, you're pretty good with that racquet.
You ought to see my backhand. (dumping spaghetti into platter)
And wait till I serve the meatballs. (demonstrates)
Shall I light the candles?

It's a must -- gracious-living-wise. As Fran starts into the living room, Bud begins to ladle meat sauce onto the spaghetti, humming operatically. In the living room, the small table has been set for two, and prominent on it is the champagne bottle that Mr. Kirk left behind, still in its cardboard bucket, but freshly i As Fran lights the candles, she notices the napkins on th table, peels a price-tag off the corner of one of them.
I see you bought some napkins.

Might as well go all the way. He carries the platter of spaghetti and meat sauce in fro the kitchen, sets it on the table, sprinkles some cheese it. Then he crosses to the coffee table, where a full martini pitcher stands in readiness, fills a couple of glasses. Fran seats herself at the table.
You know, I used to live like Robinson Crusoe -- shipwrecked among eight million people. Then one day I saw a footprint in the sand -- and there you were -- (hands her martini)
It's a wonderful thing -- dinner for two.
You usually eat alone?
Oh, no. Sometimes I have dinner with Ed Sullivan, sometimes with Dinah Shore or Perry Como -- the other night I had dinner with Mae West -- of course, she was much younger then. (toasting)
Cheers.
Cheers. They drink.
You know what we're going to do after dinner?
The dishes?
I mean, after that?
What?
You don't have to if you don't want to --
I don't?
We're going to finish that gin game.
Oh.
So I want you to keep a clear head. The door bell rings. Carrying his martini glass, Bud cros to the door, starts to open it.

Because I don't want to take advantage of you -- the way I did yesterday in bed. By now the door is open, and Bud is speaking to Fran over his shoulder. He turns, finds himself face to face with K Matuschka, who is standing grimly in the doorway.
Baxter?
Yes? Matuschka shoves him roughly aside, strides past him towa Fran, who has risen to her feet.
What's with you, Fran -- did you forget where you live?
(to Bud)
This is my brother-in-law, Karl Matuschka.
(friendly)
How do you do, Mr. Matuschka?
(pushing Bud away; to Fran)
Okay, get your clothes on. I got the cab downstairs.
Now, wait a minute. I know what you're thinking -- but it's not as bad as it looks --
(shoving him away)
It's none of my business what you do, Fran -- you're over twenty- one -- but your sister happens to think you're a lady.
All we were going to do is eat and wash the dishes --
(grabbing him)
Look, Buddy-boy -- if there wasn't a lady present, I'd clobber you.
(separating them)

All right, Karl -- I'll get dressed. She exits into the bedroom, removing her dress from the door, and closing it. Matuschka leans against the wall beside the hall door, eyeing Bud truculently. Bud raises finger to remonstrate with him -- then breaks into a nerv ingratiating smile.
Care for a martini? Champagne? (Matuschka continues glaring at him)
How about a little spaghetti with meat sauce? Made it myself. (Matuschka just scowls)
Your sister-in-law sure is terrific -- (realizes his mistake; switching abruptly)

Must be murder driving a cab in New York -- I mean, with all that cross-town traffic -- He gestures with the martini glass, spilling the contents over his shirtfront. Through the partly open hall door, D Dreyfuss sticks his head in.
Hi, Baxter. He steps into the apartment, passing Matuschka without seeing him.
How's the patient?
(quickly)
Oh, I'm fine, Doc.
Not you -- Miss Kubelik.
(stepping forward)
What's the matter with Miss Kubelik?
Oh, this is Mr. Matuschka -- he's Miss Kubelik's -- he's got a cab downstairs --
(to Dreyfuss)
Fran been sick or something? Dr. Dreyfuss looks at Bud.
No, no -- just had a little accident.
(to Dreyfuss)
What does he mean, accident?
Well, these things happen all the time --
What things? (grabbing Dreyfuss)
Say, what kind of doctor are you, anyway?
(hastily)
Oh, not that kind. He just gave her a shot and pumped her stomach out -- Behind them, the bedroom door has opened, and Fran comes out, wearing her coat over her dress.
What for?
(coming up)
Because I took some sleeping pills. But I'm all right now -- so let's go.
Why did you take sleeping pills?
(promptly)
On account of me.
(whirling on him)
You?

Who else? Matuschka lashes out with a left to Bud's jaw, and while is off balance, catches him with a right to the eye. Bud falls back against the Christmas tree, which topples with crash. Fran pulls Matuschka away from him.
Leave him alone, Karl. She kneels beside Bud.
(tenderly)
You fool -- you damn fool.
Come on, Fran.
Goodbye, Mr. Baxter. She kisses him on the cheek, rises, starts toward the doo
Goodbye, doctor. She follows Matuschka out. Bud looks after her, starry-ey
I don't want to gloat, but just between us, you had that coming to you. (tilts Bud's chin up, examines his eye)
Tch, tch, tch. Are you going to have a shiner tomorrow. Let me get my bag. (he starts out)
(calling after him)
Don't bother, Doc. It doesn't hurt a bit. He is on Cloud Nine.
Bud is coming from the elevators toward his office. He is wearing his chesterfield, bowler, and a pair of dark glas He opens the office door, starts in.
Bud crosses directly to the phone, removes his glasses revealing a swollen left eye. He dials a number.
(into phone)

Mr. Sheldrake's office? This is C.C. Baxter. Would you please tell Mr. Sheldrake I'd like to come up and see him? It's rather important. Will you call me back, please? He hangs up, takes off his hat and coat, deposits them on the clothes- tree. Then he paces around the office, rehearsing a speech out loud.
Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you. All your troubles are over. I'm going to take Miss Kubelik off your hands. (nods to himself with satisfaction)

The plain fact is, Mr. Sheldrake, that I love her. I haven't told her yet, but I thought you should be the first to know. After all, you don't really want her, and I do, and although it may sound presumptuous, she needs somebody like me. So I think it would be the thing all around -- (the phone rings and he picks it up)
-- solution-wise. (into phone)
Yes? I'll be right up. He hangs up, crosses to the door, opens it.
(to himself)
Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you -- Putting on his dark glasses, he heads for the elevators, still talking to himself.
Kirkeby and Dobisch are just stepping out of an elevator when Bud approaches. They grin smugly when they see that is wearing dark glasses.
Hi, Buddy-boy. What happened to you?
Hit by a swinging door? Or maybe a Yellow Cab? Bud pays no attention, walks right past them into the elevator, still muttering to himself. The doors close.
(as they move away from the elevators)
That guy really must've belted him.
Yeah, he's punchy. Talking to himself.
The elevator doors open.
Twenty-seven. Bud steps out. As he heads for Sheldrake's office, he continues rehearsing his speech.

You see, Mr. Sheldrake, those two days she spent in the apartment -- it made me realize how lonely I'd been before. But thanks to you, I'm in a financial position to marry her -- if I can ever square things with her family. He opens the door to Sheldrake's anteroom.
Sheldrake is pacing in front of his desk. A couple of suitcases are standing in a corner of the room. The inter buzzes, and Sheldrake presses the lever down.
Mr. Baxter is here.
Send him in. A beat, then the door opens, and Bud marches in determine
Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you --
And I've got good news for you, Baxter. All your troubles are over.
(reacting to the echo)
Sir?
I know how worried you were about Miss Kubelik -- well, stop worrying -- I'm going to take her off your hands.
(stunned)
You're going to take her off my hands?
That's right. (indicating suitcases)
I've moved out of my house -- I'm going to be staying in town, at the Athletic Club.
You left your wife?
Well, if you must know -- I fired my secretary, my secretary got to my wife, and my wife fired me. Ain't that a kick in the head?
Yeah --
Now what was your news, Baxter?
(recovering with difficulty)
It's about Miss Kubelik -- she's all right again -- so she went back home.
Swell. And don't think I've forgotten what you did for me. (opens door to adjoining office)
This way, Baxter. Bud advances slowly toward the door.
It is a slightly smaller and less lavish edition of Sheld s office. Sheldrake ushers Bud through the door, points t the chair behind the desk.
Sit down. Try it on for size. Bud obeys like an automaton, lowers himself into the chai
You like? (indicating office)
It's all yours.
Mine?
My assistant, Roy Thompson, has been shifted to the Denver office, and you're taking his place. (no reaction from Bud)
What's the matter, Baxter? You don't seem very excited.

Well, it's just that so many things have been happening so fast -- I'm very pleased -- especially for Miss Kubelik. Now that I've gotten to know her better, I think she's the kind of girl that definitely ought to be married to somebody --

Oh, sure, sure. But first the property settlement has to be worked out -- then it takes six weeks in Reno -- meanwhile, I'm going to enjoy being a bachelor for a while. (starts back toward his own office)
Oh, by the way, you can now have lunch in the executive dining room --
Yes, sir. He removes his dark glasses reflectively.
That's just one of the privileges that goes with this job. You also get a nice little expense account, the use of the executive washroom -- (breaks off, peers at Bud's face)
Say, what happened to you, Baxter?
I got kicked in the head, too.

Oh? With a shrug, he exits into his own office, closing the d behind him. Bud sits there, unconsciously bending the glasses in his hand until they suddenly snap in two. Bud glances down at the two broken halves, as though surprise by his own violence, tosses them on the desk.

We are close on the building directory. Listed under PERSONNEL is J.D. SHELDRAKE, Director, and just below tha hand is inserting the name C.C. BAXTER in the slot marked Director. The lettering is complete except for the final Camera pulls back to reveal the sign painter we saw earli working on the directory. Watching him is Bud. He is wear his chesterfield and bowler, and still has a slight welt under his left eye. It is after six o'clock, and there is very little activity in the lobby. Fran, wearing her coat over street clothes, approaches fr the direction of the elevators, stops when she sees Bud.
Good evening, Mr. Baxter. Bud turns to her in surprise, removes his bowler.
Oh, Miss Kubelik. How do you feel?
Fine. How's your eye?
Fine. There is a moment of constraint between them.
How's everything at the apartment?
Nothing's changed. You know, we never finished that gin game --
I know. (a beat)
I suppose you heard about Mr. Sheldrake --?
You mean, leaving his wife? Yeah. I'm very happy for you.
I never thought he'd do it.
I told you all along. You see, you were wrong about Mr. Sheldrake.
I guess so.

For that matter, you were wrong about me, too. What you said about those who take and those who get took? Well, Mr. Sheldrake wasn't using me -- I was using him. See? (indicating his name on directory)
Last month I was at desk 861 on the nineteenth floor -- now I'm on the twenty-seventh floor, paneled office, three windows -- so it all worked out fine -- we're both getting what we want.
Yes. (looks at her watch)
You walking to the subway?
No, thank you. (fumbling)
I -- well, to tell you the truth -- (glancing around lobby)
-- I have this heavy date for tonight -- He points off toward the newsstand. Standing there is a tall, attractive brunette, obviously waiting for someone. Fran looks off in the indicated direction.
Oh.
Aren't you meeting Mr. Sheldrake?
No. You know how people talk. So I decided it would be better if we didn't see each other till everything is settled, divorce-wise.
That's very wise.
Good night, Mr. Baxter.

Good night, Miss Kubelik. Fran walks toward the revolving doors. Bud watches her fo moment, then strides briskly across the lobby toward the newsstand. He goes right past the waiting brunette, stops front of a rack of pocket books, examines the merchandise man now comes out of a phone booth, joins the waiting brunette, and they go off together. Bud picks out a coupl of paperbacks, pays the clerk behind the counter. Stuffin book into each coat pocket, he moves slowly toward the revolving doors.
Sheldrake is swiveled around sideways behind his desk, wi a bootblack kneeling in front of him, shining his shoes. Reaching for the intercom, Sheldrake presses down one of levers.
Baxter -- would you mind stepping in her for a minute?
Yes, Mr. Sheldrake. The bootblack finishes the second shoe with a flourish, gathers up his equipment. Sheldrake tosses him a half dol
Much obliged. He exits into the anteroom as the door of the adjoining office opens and Bud comes in, carrying several charts. There is no trace left of his black eye.
(putting charts on desk)
Here's the breakdown of figures on personnel turnover. Thirty-seven percent of our female employees leave to get married, twenty-two percent quit because --
(breaking in)
You're working too hard, Baxter. It's New Year's Eve -- relax.
Yes, sir.
I suppose you'll be on the town tonight -- celebrating?
Naturally.
Me, too. I'm taking Miss Kubelik out -- I finally talked her into it --
I see.
The only thing is I'm staying at the Athletic Club -- and it's strictly stag so if you don't mind --
Don't mind what?
You know that other key to your apartment -- well, when we had that little scare about Miss Kubelik, I thought I'd better get rid of it quick -- so I threw it out the window of the commuter train.
Very clever.
Now I'll have to borrow your key.
Sorry, Mr. Sheldrake.
What do you mean, sorry?
You're not going to bring anybody up to my apartment.
I'm not just bringing anybody -- I'm bringing Miss Kubelik.
Especially not Miss Kubelik.
How's that again?
(flatly)
No key!

Baxter, I picked you for my team because I thought you were a bright young man. You realize what you're doing? Not to me -- but to yourself. Normally it takes years to work your way up to the twenty-seventh floor -- but it takes only thirty seconds to be out on the street again. You dig?
(nodding slowly)
I dig.
So what's it going to be? Without taking his eyes off Sheldrake, Bud reaches into h pocket, fishes out a key, drops it on the desk.
Now you're being bright?
Thank you, sir. He turns abruptly, starts back into his own office.

Bud comes in, shutting the door behind him, stands rooted the spot for a moment. Then he takes some pencils out of breast pocket and drops them into a container on the desk closes his account book, slams a couple of open file draw shut. As he crosses to the clothes closet, the connecting door opens and Sheldrake comes in, key in hand.
Say, Baxter -- you gave me the wrong key.
No I didn't.
(holding it out)
But this is the key to the executive washroom.
That's right, Mr. Sheldrake. I won't be needing it -- because I'm all washed up around here. He has taken his chesterfield and bowler out of the close and is putting the coat on.
What's gotten into you, Baxter?
Just following doctor's orders. I've decided to become a mensch. You know what that means? A human being.
Now hold on, Baxter --
Save it. The old payola won't work any more. Goodbye, Mr. Sheldrake. He opens the door to the anteroom, starts out.

Bud comes out of his office, carrying his bowler, strides past the secretaries and through the glass doors to the foyer. An elevator is just unloading, and beside it a handyman is cleaning out one of the cigarette receptacles Bud crosses to the elevator, and as he passes the handyma he jams his bowler on the man's head -- surrendering his crown, so to speak. The elevator doors close. The handyma straightens up, looks around in bewilderment.

Bud is in the process of packing. In the middle of the living room are several large cardboard cartons filled wi his possessions. The art posters are off the walls, the bric-a-brac has been removed from the shelves, and Bud is stowing away the last of his books and records. He crosse to the fireplace, opens one of the drawers in the cabinet above it, takes out a forty-five automatic. He holds the in the palm of his hand, studies it appraisingly. The doorbell rings. Bud snaps out of his reverie, drops t gun into one of the cartons, goes to the door and opens i Standing outside is Dr. Dreyfuss, with a plastic ice buck in his hand.
Say, Baxter -- we're having a little party and we ran out of ice -- so I was wondering --
Sure, Doc.
(stepping inside)
How come you're alone on New Year's Eve?
Well, I have things to do --
(noticing cartons)
What's this -- you packing?
Yeah -- I'm giving up the apartment. He goes into the kitchen, opens the refrigerator, starts pry out the ice-cube trays.
Where are you moving to?
I don't know. All I know is I got to get out of this place.
Sorry to lose you, Baxter.

Me? Oh, you mean my body. Don't worry, Doc -- it'll go to the University -- I'll put it in writing -- He dumps the ice-cubes, still in their trays, into the bucket Dr. Dreyfuss is holding. Then he pulls Kirkeby's unopened bottle of champagne out of the refrigerator.
Can you use a bottle of champagne?
Booze we don't need. Why don't you join us, Baxter? We got two brain surgeons, an ear, nose and throat specialist, a proctologist, and three nurses from Bellevue.
No, thanks -- I don't feel like it. Look, Doc -- in case I don't see you again -- how much do I owe you for taking care of that girl?
Forget it -- I didn't do it as a doctor -- I did it as a neighbor. (stopping in doorway)
By the way, whatever happened to her?
(airily)
You know me with girls. Easy come, easy go. Goodbye, Doc.

Happy New Year. Bud closes the door, returns to the kitchen, brings out a box of glassware and the tennis racquet. As he starts to deposit the racquet in a carton, he notices a strand of spaghetti clinging to the strings. He removes it gently, stands there twirling the limp spaghetti absently around finger.

It is five minutes before midnight, New Year's Eve. Sitti alone in the last booth is Fran, a paper hat on her head, pensive look on her face. There are two champagne glasses the table, and the usual noisemakers, but the chair oppos her is empty. Above the general hubbub, the Chinese piani can be heard playing. After a moment, Fran glances off. Threading his way through the merrymakers crowding the ba and overflowing from the booths is Sheldrake. He is in dinner clothes, topped by a paper hat. Reaching the last booth, he drops into the chair facing Fran.
Sorry it took me so long on the phone. But we're all set.
All set for what?
I rented a car -- it's going to be here at one o'clock -- we're driving to Atlantic City.
Atlantic City?
I know it's a drag -- but you can't find a hotel room in town -- not on New Year's Eve.
(a long look at Sheldrake)
Ring out the old year, ring in the new. Ring-a-ding-ding.
I didn't plan it this way, Fran -- actually, it's all Baxter's fault.
Baxter?
He wouldn't give me the key to the apartment.
He wouldn't.
Just walked out on me -- quit -- threw that big fat job right in my face.
(a faint smile)
The nerve.
That little punk -- after all I did for him! He said I couldn't bring anybody to his apartment -- especially not Miss Kubelik. What's he got against you, anyway?
(a faraway look in her eye)
I don't know. I guess that's the way it crumbles -- cookie-wise.
What are you talking about?

I'd spell it out for you -- only I can't spell. The piano player is consulting the watch on his upraised left arm. He drops the arm in a signal, and the lights go out. At the same time, he strikes up AULD LANG SYNE. All over the dimly lit room, couples get to their feet, embracing and joining in the song. In the last booth, Sheldrake leans across the table, kiss Fran.

Happy New Year, Fran. Fran's expression is preoccupied. Sheldrake faces in the direction of the pianist, and holding his glass aloft, si along with the others. As AULD LANG SYNE comes to an end, the place explodes noisily -- there is a din of horns, ratchets, and shouted greetings. The lights come up again. In the last booth, Sheldrake turns back toward Fran -- bu she is no longer there. Her paper hat lies abandoned on h vacated chair.
Fran -- (looking around)
-- where are you, Fran? He rises, cranes his neck, trying to spot her in the crow

Fran, a coat thrown over the dress she was wearing at the Rickshaw, comes down the street almost at a run. There is happy, expectant look on her face. She hurries up the ste of the house and through the front door.
Fran mounts the stairs eagerly. As she reaches the landin and heads for Bud's apartment, there is a loud, sharp rep from inside. Fran freezes momentarily, then rushes to the door.
Mr. Baxter! (pounding on door)
Mr. Baxter! Mr. Baxter! The door opens and there stands Bud, the bottle of champa he has just uncorked still foaming over in his hand. He stares at Fran unbelievingly.
(sagging with relief)
Are you all right?
I'm fine.
Are you sure? How's your knee?
I'm fine all over.
Mind if I come in?
(still stunned)
Of course not.
Fran comes in and Bud shuts the door. The room is the sam as we left it, except for an empty champagne glass standi on the coffee table.
Let me get another glass. He goes to one of the cartons, takes out a champagne glas wrapped in newspaper, starts to unwrap it.
(looking around)
Where are you going?
Who knows? Another neighborhood -- another town -- another job -- I'm on my own.
That's funny -- so am I. (Bud, pouring champagne, looks up at her)
What did you do with the cards?
(indicating carton)
In there. Fran takes the deck of cards and the gin rummy score pad of the carton, settles herself on the couch, starts to shuffle the cards expertly.
What about Mr. Sheldrake?
I'm going to send him a fruit cake every Christmas. Bud sinks down happily on the couch, and Fran holds out t deck to him.
Cut. Bud cuts a card, but doesn't look at it.
I love you, Miss Kubelik.
(cutting a card)
Seven -- (looking at Bud's card)
-- queen. She hands the deck to Bud.
Did you hear what I said, Miss Kubelik? I absolutely adore you.
(smiling)

Shut up and deal! Bud begins to deal, never taking his eyes off her. Fran removes her coat, starts picking up her cards and arrangi them. Bud, a look of pure joy on his face, deals -- and deals -- and keeps dealing. And that's about it. Story-wise.
